com.poesys.db.dto
Interface IDto

All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Comparable<IDto>
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractDto, AbstractLazyLoadingDtoProxy
public interface IDto
extends java.lang.Comparable<IDto>

Base interface for the Data Transfer Objects (DTOs). A DTO holds the data queried from the database or created by the business layer preparatory to inserting, updating, or deleting data from the database. The basic purpose of the DTO is to transfer data from the database and data access layer to the business layer. You should use these classes to get data from the data access layer through the business delegates, then transform the data into user interface DTOs that hold the data in a format suitable for use in the user interface.

Each DTO contains the straightforward transformation of the columns from the database into Java data types. It also contains the primary key object that identifies the object and contains the database columns that comprise the database primary key for the object.

The DTO supports comparison (ordinal inequalities and equality), equality comparison based on all data in the object, and hashing based on the primary key.

The DTO supports a lifecycle that starts with either status NEW or EXISTING. An in-memory factory creates a NEW object; a database query creates an EXISTING object. When you store a NEW object in the database, it becomes EXISTING. When you call a mutator (set method), it should change the status to CHANGED. When you call update(), the CHANGED status transitions to EXISTING. When you call delete(), the implementation should change the status to DELETED. When you call undoStatus(), the implementation should restore the previous status (but not necessarily the concrete state). The insert, update, and delete Data Access Object (DAO) methods also transition the status to EXISTING, DELETED, or FAILED. This latter status provides a way for batch processing, in particular, to inform the client which objects failed to process correctly. You can fix the problem, reset the status using undoStatus(), and resubmit the object for processing.

The DTO should have collections of setters (ISet objects) that implement the database-related operations on nested objects.

  • query: a setter that queries nested objects
  • insert: a setter that inserts certain kinds of nested objects (children and associations)
  • prechange: a setter that handles nested objects as required before the main update or delete operation executes
  • postchange: a setter that handles nested objects as required after the main update or delete operation executes

The DTO should also have collections of validators for insert, update, delete, and query operations. The DAO calls the validators before doing its main operation.

You should use a database constraint option (ON DELETE CASCADE, ON UPDATE SET NULL, and so on) to propagate changes along foreign keys. Not all databases support all standard options, however, and you might need to propagate deletes or updates using setters when working with some databases.

The DTO should be thread safe if you are going to cache it or otherwise use it in a multi-threaded environment. See the AbstractDto for specific suggestions on thread safety techniques.

The AbstractDto class implements a thread-safe, constructor-initialized version of this interface as a reference implementation with status undo and full processing for setters and validators.

Please see the documentation for AbstractDto for some examples of DTO coding.

Author:
Robert J. Muller
See Also:
ISet, AbstractDto

Method Detail

getPrimaryKey

IPrimaryKey getPrimaryKey()
Get the primary key of the object. The primary key uniquely identifies the object in a collection of objects.

Returns:
an IPrimaryKey primary key object

getStatus

IDto.Status getStatus()
Get the current status of the Data Transfer Object

Returns:
Status of the object

setExisting

void setExisting()
                 throws DtoStatusException
Set the status of the DTO to EXISTING if it is currently NEW.

Throws:
DtoStatusException - when the current status is not NEW

setChanged

void setChanged()
                throws DtoStatusException
Set the status of the DTO to CHANGED if it is currently EXISTING or FAILED. If the DTO is NEW, the status remains unchanged, as all changes to state are still part of the NEW object.

Throws:
DtoStatusException - when the non-NEW DTO cannot transition to the CHANGED state

setFailed

void setFailed()
Set the status of the DTO to FAILED.

delete

void delete()
            throws DtoStatusException
Mark the object as deleted if it is EXISTING or CHANGED.

Throws:
DtoStatusException - when the current status is not EXISTING or CHANGED

undoStatus

void undoStatus()
Restore the previous status of the object.

queryNestedObjects

void queryNestedObjects(java.sql.Connection connection)
                        throws java.sql.SQLException,
                               ConstraintViolationException,
                               BatchException,
                               DtoStatusException
Query all the nested objects registered with the DTO. If the factory has added a setter (ISet) for the nested object or collection, calling this method executes the setter to instantiate the nested object(s).

Parameters:
connection - the database connection for the transaction
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - when there is a problem with one of the queries
ConstraintViolationException - when the DTO has no primary key or violates some other constraint
BatchException - when there is a problem with one or more updates in a batch of updates
DtoStatusException - when there is a problem setting the nested §DTO status to EXISTING
See Also:
ISet

insertNestedObjects

void insertNestedObjects(java.sql.Connection connection)
                         throws java.sql.SQLException,
                                ConstraintViolationException,
                                BatchException,
                                DtoStatusException
Insert all the nested objects registered with the DTO. If the factory has added a setter (ISet) for the nested object or collection, calling this method executes the setter to insert the nested object(s). The nested objects are either composite children of the DTO parent or association objects with all the associated objects already stored in the database.

Parameters:
connection - the database connection for the transaction
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - when there is a problem with one of the inserts
ConstraintViolationException - when the DTO has no primary key or violates some other constraint
BatchException - when there is a problem with one or more updates in a batch of updates
DtoStatusException - when there is a problem setting an inserted DTO object to EXISTING
See Also:
ISet

preprocessNestedObjects

void preprocessNestedObjects(java.sql.Connection connection)
                             throws java.sql.SQLException,
                                    ConstraintViolationException,
                                    BatchException,
                                    DtoStatusException
Preprocess all the nested objects registered with the DTO. If the factory has added a setter (ISet) for the nested object or collection, calling this method executes the setter to handle the nested object(s) with processing appropriate to their current status. Call this method before executing the main SQL operation.

Parameters:
connection - the database connection for the transaction
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - when there is a problem with one of the operations
ConstraintViolationException - when the DTO has no primary key or violates some other constraint
BatchException - when there is a problem with one or more operations in a batch of operations
DtoStatusException - when there is a problem setting the status of a nested DTO
See Also:
ISet

Call this method after executing the main SQL operation.

Throws:

                      throws java.sql.SQLException,
                             ConstraintViolationException
Validate the DTO for querying.

Parameters:
connection - an optional transaction connection
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - when there is a problem accessing the database
ConstraintViolationException - when the DTO has no primary key, has invalid query parameters, has missing required data members, or violates some other complex constraint related to querying
